mil3.7.7:0.3: 7. Question on the Increase or Decrease of Merit and Demerit
mil3.7.7:1.2: “Venerable Nāgasena, which of the two is greater, merit or demerit?”
mil3.7.7:1.3: “Merit is greater, your majesty, demerit is small.”
mil3.7.7:1.5: “For one doing demerit, your majesty, there is the regret, ‘I have committed an evil deed’, and therefore demerit does not increase.
mil3.7.7:1.6: But for one doing merit, your majesty, there is no regret; and for one without regret gladness arises; for one who is glad joy arises; for one with a joyous mind the body calms down; one with a calmed body experiences happiness; the mind of one who is happy becomes concentrated; and one who is concentrated knows things as they really are. For this reason, merit increases.
mil3.7.7:1.7: Even if a man with his hands and feet cut off gives just a handful of lotuses to the Blessed One, he will not go to a hell realm for ninety-one eons.
mil3.7.7:1.8: For this reason, your majesty, merit is greater and demerit is small.”
